steps.title: Obtain the equipment to lead your horse.
steps.content: Obtain the equipment to lead your horse. You will need a few tools to lead your horse: halter, lead rope, gloves, and dressage whip. The halter will fit snugly yet comfortably on your horse’s head, and the lead the rope will attach to the halter. The gloves are useful to protect your hands from rope burns and/or irritation. [3] X Trustworthy Source American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals Leading organization dedicated to the prevention of animal cruelty Go to source The dressage whip is a semi-rigid rod that is about 36 to 44 inches (91 to 110 cm) in length. The semi-rigidness will prevent the horse from experiencing painful or bothersome pokes from the whip. [4] X Trustworthy Source American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals Leading organization dedicated to the prevention of animal cruelty Go to source Lead ropes come in different materials. Cotton lead ropes can be more forgiving on your hands (if you are not wearing gloves), [5] X Trustworthy Source American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals Leading organization dedicated to the prevention of animal cruelty Go to source but may rot or mildew if stored when wet. Polypropylene lead ropes have several advantages, including being soft and flexible and easy to grip. [6] X Research source Nylon lead ropes are also available. [7] X Trustworthy Source American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals Leading organization dedicated to the prevention of animal cruelty Go to source Choose a lead rope that is about 8 to 10 feet (2 to 3 m) long. A rope halter with a rope crown snap is useful when teaching a horse to yield to pressure. Pressure is sometimes needed when leading a horse. [8] X Research source Treats will also be helpful to have on hand. Examples of tasty treats include cut-up apples or carrots and horse cookies. [9] X Trustworthy Source American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals Leading organization dedicated to the prevention of animal cruelty Go to source

steps.title: Place the halter on your horse.
steps.content: Place the halter on your horse. Attach your lead rope to the halter before placing it on your horse. Holding the unbuckled halter in your left hand, stand on your horse’s left side and slowly guide your right hand over his neck to guide his head toward you. With your right hand, slowly guide the halter’s nosepiece over your horse’s muzzle and the headstall over and behind his ears. [10] X Expert Source Kate Jutagir Equestrian Specialist & Trainer Expert Interview. 31 March 2020. Do not poke your horse’s eyes as you are positioning the halter. [11] X Research source Secure the halter. Keep in mind that halters have different ways of being secured (e.g., buckles, snaps, clips). [12] X Research source Talk to your horse in a reassuring voice as you are placing the halter on him. Having the lead rope already attached will give you some control if your horse tries to pull away as you put the halter on. [13] X Research source

steps.title: Check the fit of the halter.
steps.content: Check the fit of the halter. A halter that does not fit properly will create challenges when leading a horse. You should be to fit two fingers easily and snugly between your horse and the noseband. [14] X Research source Adjust the halter accordingly if it fits too tightly or too loosely. Your horse may signal his discomfort if the halter is too tight on his head or behind his ears.

steps.title: Stand on your horse’s left side.
steps.content: Stand on your horse’s left side. A horse’s left side is the customary position to lead a horse. You can stand so that you are either even with your horse’s head or about halfway between his head and shoulder. Stand about 12 inches (30 cm) away from your horse. [15] X Trustworthy Source American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals Leading organization dedicated to the prevention of animal cruelty Go to source Leading a horse is possible from the lead (in front of your horse) or drive positions (behind your horse’s withers), but is not as safe as standing by your horse’s side.

steps.title: Hold the lead rope.
steps.content: Hold the lead rope. How you hold the lead rope is essential to safely leading your horse. Hold the lead rope with your right hand. [16] X Research source Fold or coil the excess lead rope in your left hand. [17] X Research source Never wrap the lead rope around your hand—if your horse decides to bolt, you could get dragged by your horse and seriously injure yourself. Keep the excess lead rope off of the ground to prevent you or your horse from tripping over it. [18] X Research source

steps.title: Apply pressure with your lead rope.
steps.content: Apply pressure with your lead rope. An important aspect of leading your horse is teaching him how to yield his hindquarters from a standstill. To begin, face your horse’s left side. With the lead rope in your left hand, apply even pressure with the lead rope to get your horse to turn his head turns towards you. Teaching your horse to yield his hindquarters is important because he may have the tendency to do a partial halt when being led: stopping his front legs while moving his hindquarters in a quarter circle. [19] X Research source A full halt is when your horse can yield both his front and hindquarters.

steps.title: Tap your horse’s left ankle with the dressage whip.
steps.content: Tap your horse’s left ankle with the dressage whip. Hold the dressage whip in your right hand. Use gentle taps on your horse’s left ankle (inside hind leg) to coax your horse to move that leg in, forward and in front the outside hind leg. [20] X Trustworthy Source American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals Leading organization dedicated to the prevention of animal cruelty Go to source Continue tapping until he move his inside hind leg correctly. [21] X Trustworthy Source American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals Leading organization dedicated to the prevention of animal cruelty Go to source Your horse may not care for the tap of the dressage whip, but it will not hurt him. Space your taps about one second apart. [22] X Trustworthy Source American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals Leading organization dedicated to the prevention of animal cruelty Go to source When your horse can yield his hindquarters when you are on his left side, switch to his right side. [23] X Trustworthy Source American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals Leading organization dedicated to the prevention of animal cruelty Go to source

steps.title: Practice consistently.
steps.content: Practice consistently. [24] X Expert Source Kate Jutagir Equestrian Specialist & Trainer Expert Interview. 31 March 2020. Initially, your horse may kick the leg you are tapping. In addition, he may move his outside hind leg. [25] X Trustworthy Source American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals Leading organization dedicated to the prevention of animal cruelty Go to source If he moves his outside hind leg, follow his movements, but continue to tap on his inside leg. Eventually, he will stop moving the outside hind leg and move only the inside hind leg. Keep your practice sessions relatively short—about 10 to 15 minutes. [26] X Research source

steps.title: Give your horse a verbal cue to move forward.
steps.content: Give your horse a verbal cue to move forward. Position yourself as when you taught him to yield his hindquarters: facing his left side with the lead rope in your left hand and the dressage whip in your right hand. As you take your first step forward, give your horse a verbal cue (e.g., a soft clucking or kissing noise). [27] X Trustworthy Source American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals Leading organization dedicated to the prevention of animal cruelty Go to source Although you will be moving forward, you will need to face him to closely watch his forward movements. [28] X Trustworthy Source American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals Leading organization dedicated to the prevention of animal cruelty Go to source Pick a spot about 10 feet (3 m) in front of you before starting your forward movement. [29] X Trustworthy Source American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals Leading organization dedicated to the prevention of animal cruelty Go to source

steps.title: Tap your horse’s hips.
steps.content: Tap your horse’s hips. Start tapping your horse’s hip with the whip after you give the verbal cue, but before your foot hits the ground. The timing of when you start tapping is important so that your horse learns to associate the verbal cue with forward movement. [30] X Trustworthy Source American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals Leading organization dedicated to the prevention of animal cruelty Go to source Space the taps about one second apart. [31] X Trustworthy Source American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals Leading organization dedicated to the prevention of animal cruelty Go to source Continue tapping until your horse moves forward. If he moves in any direction other than forward, follow his movements and continue tapping. Make sure not to apply any additional pressure to his halter or lead rope if he moves in the wrong direction. [32] X Trustworthy Source American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals Leading organization dedicated to the prevention of animal cruelty Go to source Stop the tapping immediately when he begins to step forward. [33] X Trustworthy Source American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals Leading organization dedicated to the prevention of animal cruelty Go to source

steps.title: Say ‘whoa.
steps.content: Say ‘whoa. ’ This verbal cue indicates to your horse that he has walked forward to the correct location. He may not understand this cue initially, and may even continue walking past the desired location. If he does this, say ‘whoa’ again and apply backward pressure to his lead rope to encourage him to walk backward to the right spot. [34] X Trustworthy Source American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals Leading organization dedicated to the prevention of animal cruelty Go to source It is important for you to stop tapping when he reaches the correct spot. [35] X Trustworthy Source American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals Leading organization dedicated to the prevention of animal cruelty Go to source In time, he should be able to stop according to your verbal ‘whoa,’ rather than when you stop tapping.

steps.title: Lead your horse through a narrow opening.
steps.content: Lead your horse through a narrow opening. Narrow openings, such as a stall door, can be dangerous to move through with your horse. He may be reluctant to move forward because the inside of the area looks different from the outside. This reluctance may lead to bolting or extreme resistance, both of which could injure you. To safely lead your horse through a narrow opening, it is advisable for you to walk through the opening first, then let your horse walk through when he is calm. [36] X Research source Make sure to quickly move to the side of the opening after you move through and before you cue your horse to move forward. This will prevent your horse from crowding you as he walks through the opening.

steps.title: Lead your horse through a swing gate.
steps.content: Lead your horse through a swing gate. A swing gate is wider than a stall door. However, you will still need to control your horse as he moves through it. While leading your horse from his left side, approach the gate with as much room as possible to open the gate. Unlatch the gate with one hand while keeping a firm hold on your horse’s lead rope with your other hand. Open the gate widely enough for you and your horse to walk through easily. Your horse should not have to back up and reposition to get through the gate. Make sure to swing the gate closed when you and your horse have gone through it to prevent other animals from entering through the gate. Do not walk in front of the horse when walking through the gate. Horses tend to move quickly through openings, and he may injure you if he moves quickly when you are in front of him.

steps.title: Remove the halter and lead rope.
steps.content: Remove the halter and lead rope. Once you and your horse have safely moved through the opening, you can release him by removing his halter and lead rope. You should remove his lead rope before removing his halter. This will prevent your horse from rearing back and developing a bad habit of pulling on his halter. [37] X Expert Source Kate Jutagir Equestrian Specialist & Trainer Expert Interview. 31 March 2020. Before removing the halter and lead rope, turn your horse so that he is facing you and the opening. [38] X Research source Although this may be easier said than done, do not let your horse bolt after being released. You may want to consult with your veterinarian or equine behaviorist for tips on how to keep your horse from bolting.
